author: sauliusgrigaitis
content:
On discussion regarding block numbering after the merge - my main focus was on how to solve: 

Alice: "I sent you X ETH on block #10000000"
Bob: "There is no such block"/"The block doesn't contain the transaction"

So not focusing on power users, as there probably will not be problems getting familiar with two numbers (Execution layer  `block_number` and Consensus layer slot number). But for regular users maybe we can try to expose the `block_number` as the main number. This "discounts" the importance of the Consensus layer a bit as slot number would not be seen as *the main number*, but overall it looks like a solution that would not confuse regular users. There still would be some UI/UX challenges, for example, explorers maybe should show only non-empty slots by default (nice sequence of `block_numbers`), however, there should be an option to see empty slots too. Anyway, I think somebody could try to reach regular users and ask which way looks less confusing.

author: jgm
content:
Why would you use block numbers rather than transaction hashes for transaction identification?  Blocks have many transactions, so a block number by itself isn't a lot of use.

Although if you wanted to you could continue to use the execution layer block number.

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: This example was an oral conversation, but my main point is that block numbers are exposed widely. So users will be very confused if after merge they see slot numbers

author: potuz
content: I agree with <@144468805697929216> and just wanted to stress that: users and stakers have very different profile. Consensus slot will only be relevant to the latter, just as difficulty is only relevant to miners now and not to the rest of the world. Block number `X` will continue to mean execution block `X` to most, and when it actually is meant to be a consensus block in slot `X` then the interlocutor will be a staker/dev that will know this
